TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Mild low back pain
   24 Hour Events:
   - Started levofloxacin for presumed CAP
   - Nasal swabs for Flu and put on Resp precautions. No resp antigens
   detected. Urine legionella negative. Sputum GS 4+ GPCs.
   - Extubated in AM; Increased work of breathing and alkalotic on ABG
   7.5/29/85/23. Desaturated to 80s on Ventimask. CXR with increasing
   pulmonary edema and worsening RLL consolidation. RR improved to 20s on
   CPap and sats remained in 90s. Became unfomfortable in CPAP after 2
   hours. Maintained on face mask Hiflow 100% and repeat ABG
   7.47/33/123/25.
   - Added CIWA scale as patient reported daily [**2-3**] etoh intake x 20 yrs
   and appeared tremulous prior to being febrile.
   - Ck trending up 276 > 301 > 327 > 329
   - Febrile to 104.8 rectal at 10 pm. Recultured. Started Zosyn and d/cd
   Levaquin.
   - TTE - Moderate [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) 4139**]. Mild LVH.  EF 40% infero-lateral and
   apical hypokinesis.  No thrombi. No AS. 1+ AI. 1+ MR. moderate
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension
   Allergies:
   Morphine
   Unknown;
   Amlodipine
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Levofloxacin - [**2119-6-21**] 10:30 AM
   Vancomycin - [**2119-6-21**] 06:00 PM
   Piperacillin - [**2119-6-22**] 07:11 AM
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 650 units/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Famotidine (Pepcid) - [**2119-6-21**] 09:15 AM
   Fentanyl - [**2119-6-21**] 09:45 AM
   Metoprolol - [**2119-6-21**] 05:40 PM
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2119-6-21**] 06:00 PM
   Diazepam (Valium) - [**2119-6-21**] 08:00 PM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   none
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Mild chronic low back pain. Denies CP, SOB, nausea, dizziness,
   diaphoresis. Continued sputum production.

   GENERAL: Elderly man with face mask in NAD. A and Ox3
   HEENT: PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the
   oral mucosa.
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 10 cm.
   CARDIAC: Mild burns on left anterior chest with erythema, no
   tenderness. PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line.
   RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.

   ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:14.2/33.4/1.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:329/5/0.77, ALT / AST:118/193, Alk Phos / T Bili:36/1.0,
   Differential-Neuts:71.0 %, Band:4.0 %, Lymph:14.0 %, Mono:11.0 %,
   Eos:0.0 %, Lactic Acid:1.5 mmol/L, Albumin:3.8 g/dL, LDH:366 IU/L,
   Ca++:8.2 mg/dL, Mg++:2.6 mg/dL, PO4:5.7 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.
   .
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI. CKs appear to be close to peaked, but are still
   mildy uptrending. Echo with infero-lateral and apical hypokinesis. Plan
   for cath later on today.
   - Continue ASA, Beta-blocker, Plavix
   - Continue heparin IV gtt for medical management of NSTEMI
   - No integrillin given age and renal failure
   - Statin, check lipid panel in AM and follow LFTs given chronic
   transaminitis
   - Serial ECGs, [**Year (4 digits) 1174**] CEs to confirm declining
   - Consider cath in AM pending clinical course
   .
   PUMP: Acute decompensated CHF with newly depressed EF 35-40% with mild
   global HK on echo at OSH. Intubated for acute pulmonary edema at OSH
   and respiratory failure.
   - Beta-blocker
   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - Echo in AM
   - I/O goal even overnight pending repeat labs
   - Attempt to wean vent and extubate
   .
   RHYTHM: Telemetry.
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Intubated at OSH for dyspnea thought to be
   secondary to decompensated heart failure in setting of ACS. Also cannot
   r/o PNA/infiltrate given leukocytosis, fever. Patient
s FiO2 has been
   weaned down overnight, has been tolerating pressure support well
   - continue mild diuresis as above
   - continue to wean down on ventilatory support with goal to extubate
   - patient was switched overnight from propofol and fentanyl to
   versed/fentanyl
   .
   FEVER: [**Month (only) 11**] be stress reaction in setting of MI, however was complaining
   of URI type symptoms at office visit in addition to SOB. No
   leukocytosis at OSH. If is indication of infection, sources could be
   pulmonary (cough, unable to r/o infiltrate on CXR), abdominal with
   increased transaminitis.
   - Hold on antibiotics for now as source unclear
   - [**Name (NI) **] fever curve, WBC count
   - Send blood cultures
   - f/u cultures from OSH (BCx, UCx)
   .
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: Cre 1.5 increased from baseline 1.0 in setting of
   diuresis for acute pulmonary edema and transient hypotension at OSH,
   most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology however consider
   cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.
   - Urine lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - given mucomyst prior to cath
   .
   TRANSAMINITIS: Chronically elevated but higher than recent baseline,
   monitor daily in setting of initiating statin therapy. Also no
   abdominal pain, Tbili elevation to suggest acute cholangitis/process.
   Also acute hepatitis could be cause of increased elevation
   - [**Name (NI) 1174**] LFTs, abdominal exam
   - consider checking hepatitis serologies
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   20 Gauge - [**2119-6-21**] 05:41 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male who presented with a history of hypertension and was found to have Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) complicated by left ventricular systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema, resulting in respiratory failure.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors, including:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL, which is an increase from the baseline level of 1.0 mg/dL.
2. Transaminitis, with elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to chronic liver disease or acute hepatitis.
3. Fever, which could be related to a stress reaction, infection, or other causes.
4. Respiratory failure, which has required intubation and mechanical ventilation.
5. Cardiac dysfunction, with a depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35-40%, and mild global hypokinesis on echocardiogram.
6. Acute pulmonary edema, which has required diuresis and ventilation support.

The patient's medical conditions and medications include:

1. NSTEMI, treated with aspirin, beta-blocker, and Plavix.
2. Acute pulmonary edema, treated with diuresis and ventilation support.
3. Acute kidney injury, treated with renally dosed medications.
4. Transaminitis, treated with monitoring of liver enzymes and consideration of hepatitis serologies.
5. Fever, treated with antibiotics and consideration of other causes.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Aspirin
2. Beta-blocker
3. Plavix
4. Heparin
5. Metoprolol
6. Furosemide
7. Diazepam
8. Famotidine
9. Fentanyl
10. Versed

The patient's laboratory results include:

1. Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
2. Liver enzymes: elevated
3. White blood cell count: 8.4 K/uL
4. Hemoglobin: 12.0 g/dL
5. Platelet count: 98 K/uL
6. Troponin-T: 0.99 ng/mL
7. Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
8. Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
9. LDH: 366 IU/L
10. Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL
11. Magnesium: 2.6 mg/dL
12. Phosphorus: 5.7 mg/dL

The patient's clinical course is complicated by several factors, including the possibility of infection, cardiac dysfunction, and acute kidney injury. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.
   .
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI. No prior known history of CAD with normal
   stress-echo in [**2117**]. History and downtrending cardiac enzymes suggest
   event >48 hours prior. Echo at OSH reveals global HK without clear
   focal WMA and newly depressed EF. ECG with T wave inversions suspicious
   for apical ballooning, although unclear evaluation of degree of apical
   hypokinesis on OSH ECHO
   - ASA
   - Beta-blocker
   - Plavix 300, then 75 daily
   - Restart heparin IV gtt pending coags
   - No integrillin given with resolving ACS (enzymes trending down) and
   renal failure
   - Statin, check lipid panel in AM and follow LFTs given chronic
   transaminitis
   - Serial ECGs, [**Year (4 digits) 1174**] CEs to confirm declining
   - Consider cath in AM pending clinical course
   .

   global HK on echo at OSH. Intubated for acute pulmonary edema at OSH

   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - Echo in AM

   - Attempt to wean vent and extubate

s FiO2 has been

   of URI type symptoms at office visit in addition to SOB. No
   leukocytosis at OSH. If is indication of infection, sources could be
   pulmonary (cough, unable to r/o infiltrate on CXR), abdominal with
   increased transaminitis.

   .

   most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology however consider
   cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a chief complaint of mild low back pain. He was previously treated for presumed community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) with levofloxacin, but was later found to have non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) complicated by left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema, resulting in respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated for acute pulmonary edema, with increasing pulmonary edema and worsening right lower lobe (RLL) consolidation on chest X-ray (CXR). He is receiving CPAP and has been weaned down overnight.
* Cardiac: NSTEMI, with newly depressed EF (35-40%) and mild global hypokinesis on echocardiogram (echo) at OSH. He is receiving beta-blocker therapy and is being considered for cardiac catheterization (cath).
* Renal: Acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL, which is increased from baseline. He is receiving diuretics and is being monitored for urine lytes.
* Hepatic: Transaminitis, with elevated liver enzymes, which is being monitored daily.
* Fever: The patient has a fever of 104.8°F (rectal), which is being treated with antibiotics, but the source of the fever is unclear.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and LV systolic dysfunction put him at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's acute pulmonary edema and respiratory failure put him at risk for respiratory complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure put him at risk for further kidney damage, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.
4. Hepatic complications: The patient's transaminitis put him at risk for further liver damage, jaundice, and coagulopathy.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis put him at risk for infection, which could be secondary to pneumonia, urinary tract infection (UTI), or another source.
6. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and platelet count of 98,000/μL put him at risk for bleeding complications.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glycemic control is a concern, as he is at risk for hyperglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis.

In terms of management, the patient is being treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and beta-blocker therapy, and is being monitored for cardiac, respiratory, renal, and hepatic complications. He is also being considered for cardiac catheterization and may require further interventions such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted with a diagnosis of NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema resulting in respiratory failure. He was intubated at the onset of respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition has been complicated by fever, acute renal failure, and transaminitis. He has been receiving antibiotics for presumed CAP, but the source of the infection is unclear. His condition has been stable overnight, with his FiO2 being weaned down and his pressure support being tolerated well.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Continued LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema
	* Potential for cardiogenic shock
	* Risk of cardiac arrhythmias
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia or pulmonary infiltrate
	* Respiratory failure requiring continued mechanical ventilation
	* Risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute renal failure
	* Risk of chronic kidney disease
	* Need for close monitoring of renal function
4. Infection Complications:
	* Unidentified source of infection
	* Risk of sepsis
	* Need for continued antibiotic therapy
5. Neurological Complications:
	* Risk of delirium or altered mental status
	* Need for close monitoring of neurological status
6. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Risk of gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Need for close monitoring of gastrointestinal status
7. Hematological Complications:
	* Risk of bleeding complications due to platelet dysfunction
	* Need for close monitoring of hematological status

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue ASA, beta-blocker, and Plavix to manage NSTEMI
2. Continue heparin IV gtt for medical management of NSTEMI
3. Plan for cath today to assess coronary arteries
4. Continue statin therapy
5. Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias
6. Continue mechanical ventilation and wean down FiO2 as tolerated
7. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure
8. Continue antibiotic therapy for presumed CAP
9. Monitor for signs of infection
10. Monitor for signs of delirium or altered mental status
11. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding
12. Monitor for signs of bleeding complications due to platelet dysfunction

   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.
   .
   Respiratory failure/Pneumonia: ABG supports hypoxic resp failure. CXR
   supports worsening RLL pneumonia. Pneumonia diagnosis further supported
   by sputum GS findings, fever, CXR and leukocytosis. Patient likely
   community aquired pna as outpatient but was broadened to Vanco/Zosyn
   overnight given worsening. However, patient did improve oxygenation
   with CPAP and diuresis overnight which supports at least a component of
   pulmonary edema to his decompensation. Now saturating well on face
   tent.

   diuresis for acute pulmonary edema and transient hypotension at OSH,
   most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology however consider
   cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.
   - Renally dose meds

   monitor daily in setting of initiating statin therapy. Also no
   abdominal pain, Tbili elevation to suggest acute cholangitis/process.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a chief complaint of mild low back pain. He was admitted with suspected community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and was started on levofloxacin. However, his condition deteriorated, and he developed respiratory failure, acute pulmonary edema, and worsening right lower lobe (RLL) consolidation.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil percentage
* Elevated creatine kinase (CK) and CKMB levels, indicating possible myocardial damage
* Elevated troponin-T levels, indicating possible cardiac damage
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and liver enzymes (ALT and AST), indicating possible liver damage
* Elevated creatinine (Cr) levels, indicating possible acute renal failure

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Mild burns on the left anterior chest with erythema and no tenderness
* Faint end-expiratory crackles in the right base
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with no masses or bruits

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, and he has a history of ethanol abuse.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, and he may require mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute pulmonary edema: The patient's acute pulmonary edema may persist or worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial damage may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further fluid overload and electrolyte imbalance.
5. Liver damage: The patient's liver damage may lead to further liver enzyme elevation, jaundice, or liver failure.
6. Ethanol withdrawal: The patient's ethanol abuse may lead to withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, seizures, or delirium.
7. Infection: The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to sepsis or septic shock.
8. Thromboembolic complications: The patient's history of hypertension and cardiac disease may increase his risk of thromboembolic complications, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, the plan of care includes:

1. Continuing antibiotics and antiviral therapy
2. Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and oxygenation
3. Monitoring the patient's cardiac status and managing any cardiac complications
4. Managing the patient's acute renal failure and fluid overload
5. Monitoring the patient's liver function and managing any liver damage
6. Managing the patient's ethanol withdrawal symptoms
7. Monitoring the patient's infection and sepsis status
8. Considering thromboembolic prophylaxis and monitoring for any thromboembolic complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who presented with chest congestion, nausea, and was found to have Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) complicated by Left Ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema resulting in respiratory failure. He was intubated at the emergency department and was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). His condition has been deteriorating, with worsening respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and respiratory support, but his condition remains unstable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is worsening, and he may require further respiratory support or intubation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a confirmed diagnosis of pneumonia, and further treatment is needed to manage the infection.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to his underlying medical conditions and may require further treatment and management.
4. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient's NSTEMI and LV systolic dysfunction suggest underlying coronary artery disease, which may require further evaluation and management.
5. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's condition is unstable, and he may be at risk for cardiac arrest if not closely monitored and managed.
6. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which requires prompt recognition and management.
7. Abdominal Complications: The patient's transaminitis and elevated liver enzymes may indicate abdominal complications, such as acute cholangitis or hepatitis, which require further evaluation and management.
8. Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease if not managed appropriately.
9. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's underlying coronary artery disease and LV systolic dysfunction may increase his risk for cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and diuretics to manage the patient's pneumonia and acute kidney injury.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider further respiratory support or intubation if necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's coronary artery disease with aspirin, beta-blockers, and statins.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider further evaluation and management of his LV systolic dysfunction.
5. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's abdominal symptoms and transaminitis.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider further treatment and management of his acute kidney injury.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.
8. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's potential sepsis, including blood cultures and antibiotic management.

Chief Complaint: Mild low back pain
   24 Hour Events:
   - Started levofloxacin for presumed CAP
   - Nasal swabs for Flu and put on Resp precautions. No resp antigens
   detected. Urine legionella negative. Sputum GS 4+ GPCs.
   - Extubated in AM; Increased work of breathing and alkalotic on ABG
   7.5/29/85/23. Desaturated to 80s on Ventimask. CXR with increasing
   pulmonary edema and worsening RLL consolidation. RR improved to 20s on
   CPap and sats remained in 90s. Became unfomfortable in CPAP after 2
   hours. Maintained on face mask Hiflow 100% and repeat ABG
   7.47/33/123/25.
   - Added CIWA scale as patient reported daily [**2-3**] etoh intake x 20 yrs
   and appeared tremulous prior to being febrile.
   - Ck trending up 276 > 301 > 327 > 329
   - Febrile to 104.8 rectal at 10 pm. Recultured. Started Zosyn and d/cd
   Levaquin.
   - TTE - Moderate [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) 4139**]. Mild LVH.  EF 40% infero-lateral and
   apical hypokinesis.  No thrombi. No AS. 1+ AI. 1+ MR. moderate
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension
   Allergies:
   Morphine

   Assessment and Plan
   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.
   .
   Respiratory failure/Pneumonia: ABG supports hypoxic resp failure. CXR
   supports worsening RLL pneumonia. Pneumonia diagnosis further supported
   by sputum GS findings, fever, CXR and leukocytosis. Patient likely
   community aquired pna as outpatient but was broadened to Vanco/Zosyn
   overnight given worsening. However, patient did improve oxygenation
   with CPAP and diuresis overnight which supports at least a component of
   pulmonary edema to his decompensation. Now saturating well on face
   tent.
   -  Continue Vanco/Zosyn for now pending culture results
   -  F/u respiratory viral studies
   - Continue droplet precautions
   - Repeat ABG this am to ensure patient with hypercarbia
   - F/u culture data
   - CIS
   - Although patient does appear HD c/w sepsis plan to keep I/Os at least
   even to net 500cc positive
   .
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI. CKs appear to be close to peaked, but are still
   mildy uptrending. Echo with infero-lateral and apical hypokinesis. Plan
   for cath later on today.
   - Continue ASA, Beta-blocker, Plavix
   - Continue heparin IV gtt for medical management of NSTEMI
   - No integrillin given age and renal failure
   - Continue statin
   - Serial ECGs, trend CEs to confirm declining
   - Plan for cath today. Plan for precath hydration with bicarb.
   .
   PUMP: Acute decompensated CHF with newly depressed EF 35-40% with
   inferolat and apical HK. - Beta-blocker
   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - I/O goal even
   .
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: Cre 2  increased from baseline 1.0 in setting of
   diuresis for acute pulmonary edema and transient hypotension at OSH,
   most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology however consider
   cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.
   - Urine lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - give mucomyst and bicarb prior to cath
   .
   TRANSAMINITIS: Chronically elevated but higher than recent baseline,
   monitor daily in setting of initiating statin therapy. Also no
   abdominal pain, Tbili elevation to suggest acute cholangitis/process.
   Also acute hepatitis could be cause of increased elevation
   - trend LFTs, abdominal exam
   - consider checking hepatitis serologies
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of hypertension who presents with mild low back pain, chest congestion, and nausea. He was found to have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema resulting in respiratory failure. He was started on antibiotics for presumed community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and was intubated due to increased work of breathing. He was extubated in the morning but required reintubation due to desaturation. He is currently on face mask high-flow oxygen and is being treated for sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, with worsening pneumonia and pulmonary edema. He may require continued respiratory support and close monitoring.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has NSTEMI and LV systolic dysfunction, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
4. Sepsis: The patient is being treated for sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires close monitoring and prompt treatment.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is worsening, and he may require continued antibiotics and respiratory support to manage his symptoms.
6. Cardiac catheterization: The patient is scheduled for cardiac catheterization, which carries risks such as bleeding, infection, and cardiac complications.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk for further decline in renal function, which may require dialysis.
8. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, which may indicate hepatic dysfunction or injury.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical conditions, including respiratory failure, cardiac complications, acute kidney injury, sepsis, pneumonia, and cardiac catheterization.

Summary:

The patient, a 24-year-old male, was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of mild low back pain. He was started on levofloxacin for presumed community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). However, his condition worsened, and he developed increasing pulmonary edema and worsening right lower lobe (RLL) consolidation on chest X-ray. He was extubated in the morning but required reintubation due to increased work of breathing and alkalotic pH on arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. He was febrile to 104.8°C and was started on Zosyn and discontinued on levofloxacin. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed moderate mitral regurgitation, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and 40% infero-lateral and apical hypokinesis.

The patient has a history of daily ethanol intake for 20 years and appears tremulous prior to being febrile, indicating possible alcohol withdrawal syndrome. He also has a history of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and coronary ischemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's worsening condition and high fever suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pulmonary edema and worsening RLL consolidation on chest X-ray indicate the risk of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of ACS and coronary ischemia, along with his current condition, suggest the risk of cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, or cardiac failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of alcohol withdrawal syndrome and his current condition suggest the risk of neurological complications such as seizures, delirium, or encephalopathy.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of stress ulcer prophylaxis and his current condition suggest the risk of gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.
6. Renal complications: The patient's high creatinine levels and his current condition suggest the risk of renal complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Given the patient's complex condition, close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.
   Respiratory failure/Pneumonia:  4+ GPC with prelim cx of S. aureus from
   sputum.  On Vano.  Tmax 101.9 but HD stable.  O2 sats in high 90's,
   occasionally drop to low 90's with agitartion but improve with face
   tent.  Currently on nc. Viral studies negative.
   -  Continue Vanco/Zosyn for now pending culture results
   - F/u culture data
   - CIS
   - will pull foley now that clincially improving
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI: Cath showed clean coronaries, NSTEMI possibly
   caused by thrombus that had since resolved with medical therapy.
   - Continue ASA, Beta-blocker, Plavix
   - Continue heparin IV gtt for now which had been kept on overnight in
   case of ventricular thrombus though none seen on echo - will consider
   d/c today
   - Continue statin
   - Serial ECGs, trend CEs to confirm declining
   PUMP:  Decompenstation of CHF significantly improved.  Echo with newly
   depressed EF 35-40% with inferolat and apical HK.  Kept postive fluid
   balance overnight given septic picture in setting on large PNA
   - Beta-blocker
   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - I/O goal even to +500cc today
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: Cr trending down, at 1.7 this morning.  Baseline
   1.0, elevation is most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology
   however consider cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.
   - Renally dose meds
   - got mucomyst and bicarb prior to cath
   TRANSAMINITIS: Chronically elevated but higher than recent baseline,
   monitor daily in setting of initiating statin therapy. Also no
   abdominal pain, Tbili elevation to suggest acute cholangitis/process.
   Also acute hepatitis could be cause of increased elevation.  Abd exam
   continues to be benign
   - trend LFTs, abdominal exam
   - will check hepatitis serologies if trend up. Had normal serologies
   within last 8 years.
   EtOH abuse: Patient endorses history of etoh abuse. Was on CIWA
   previously, now off.  Has essential tremor.
   Essential tremor: On propnolol at baseline
   - Continue metoprolol for now. Will consider transitioning back to
   propanolol this morning given clean cath

   occasionally drop to low 90's with agitartion but improve with face

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a chief complaint of NSTEMI, complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema resulting in respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, bacterial pneumonia, fever, alcohol abuse, acute coronary syndrome, and pulmonary edema.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.9°C, heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 150/71 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is improving, with oxygen saturation in the high 90s and occasionally dropping to low 90s with agitation, but improving with face tent. The patient is on nasal cannula oxygen and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, creatine kinase (CK), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating cardiac injury and muscle damage. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's imaging studies show clean coronaries on catheterization, but with evidence of pulmonary edema and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) on chest X-ray. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus rhythm with ST-segment depression.

The patient's plan of care includes continued treatment with vancomycin and zosyn for pneumonia, continued heparin infusion for anticoagulation, and continued beta-blocker therapy for cardiac stabilization. The patient will also receive serial ECGs and trend creatine kinase levels to confirm declining cardiac enzyme levels.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to be complicated by bacteremia, which may lead to sepsis and organ failure.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to be caused by prerenal/ATN etiology, but consideration should be given to cardiogenic component in the setting of new depressed EF.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac injury and muscle damage may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to pneumonia and ARDS, leading to respiratory arrest.
5. Sepsis: The patient's septic picture may worsen due to pneumonia and bacteremia, leading to multi-organ failure.
6. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac failure may worsen due to cardiogenic shock, leading to cardiac arrest.
7. Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other parts of the body, leading to sepsis and organ failure.
8. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may worsen due to prerenal/ATN etiology, leading to end-stage renal disease.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of hypertension, who presented with chest congestion, nausea, and a diagnosis of NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema. He has developed acute renal failure, pneumonia, and fever. He is currently receiving treatment for these conditions, including antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and diuretics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is trending down, but it is still elevated at 1.7 mg/dL. The patient is at risk for further renal deterioration due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a confirmed diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema, which can lead to further cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is at risk for further infections, including sepsis.
5. Diarrhea: The patient has developed loose stools, which can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which can indicate liver damage or inflammation.
7. Essential tremor: The patient has a history of essential tremor, which can be exacerbated by medications or other medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and monitor for signs of improvement.
2. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic complications.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust medications as necessary.
4. Consider adding an ACE inhibitor to the patient's medication regimen to improve cardiac function.
5. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust medications as necessary to prevent further liver damage.
6. Consider sending the patient for further evaluation and treatment for his essential tremor.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medications as necessary to prevent further imbalances.
8. Consider sending the patient for further evaluation and treatment for his diarrhea.

   82M h/o HTN presents with >48 hours chest congestion, nausea found to
   have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary
   edema resulting in respiratory failure.  Also with new loose stool.
   Respiratory failure/Pneumonia:  4+ GPC with prelim cx of S. aureus from
   sputum.  On Vano.  Tmax 101.9 but HD stable.  O2 sats in high 90's,
   occasionally drop to low 90's with agitartion but improve with face
   tent.  Currently on nc. Viral studies negative.
   -  Continue Vanco for now pending culture results, will d/c Zosyn
   - F/u culture data
   - CIS
   - will pull foley now that clinically improving
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI: Cath showed clean coronaries, NSTEMI possibly
   caused by thrombus that had since resolved with medical therapy.
   - Continue ASA, Beta-blocker, Plavix for 6-12 months of therapy
   - Continue heparin IV gtt for now which had been kept on overnight in
   case of ventricular thrombus though none seen on cath - will consider
   d/c today
   - Continue statin
   PUMP:  Decompenstation of CHF significantly improved.  Echo with newly
   depressed EF 35-40% with inferolat and apical HK.  Kept postive fluid
   balance overnight given septic picture in setting on large PNA
   - Beta-blocker
   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - I/O goal even to +500cc today, will not further diurese
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: Cr trending down, at 1.7 this morning.  Baseline
   1.0, elevation is most likely consistent with prerenal/ATN etiology
   however consider cardiogenic component in setting of new depressed EF.
   - Renally dose meds
   TRANSAMINITIS: Chronically elevated but higher than recent baseline,
   monitor daily in setting of initiating statin therapy. Also no
   abdominal pain, Tbili elevation to suggest acute cholangitis/process.
   Also acute hepatitis could be cause of increased elevation.  Abd exam
   continues to be benign
   - trend LFTs, abdominal exam
   - will check hepatitis serologies if trend up. Had normal serologies
   within last 8 years.
   EtOH abuse: Patient endorses history of etoh abuse. Was on CIWA
   previously, now off.  Has essential tremor.
   ESSENTIAL TREMOR: On propnolol at baseline
   - will change back to home propanolol

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of hypertension, who presented with chest congestion, nausea, and new loose stool. He was found to have NSTEMI complicated by LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema, resulting in respiratory failure. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been receiving antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and medications for blood pressure control, cardiac function, and cholesterol management.

The patient's condition has been improving, with his oxygen saturation in the high 90s, and his respiratory rate has decreased. His blood pressure has been stable, and his cardiac function has improved. However, he still requires mechanical ventilation and has a central venous catheter in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his lung function does not improve, or if he develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's LV systolic dysfunction and acute pulmonary edema may lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid management and may require dialysis.
4. Infection: The patient's history of sepsis and pneumonia may lead to further infection, such as bloodstream infection or urinary tract infection.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's diarrhea may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, and may lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of essential tremor and recent use of propofol may lead to neurological complications such as seizures or delirium.
7. Bleeding Complications: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and platelet inhibitors may lead to bleeding complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition will continue to be monitored closely, and his treatment plan will be adjusted as necessary. He will continue to receive antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and medications for blood pressure control, cardiac function, and cholesterol management. His fluid balance will be closely monitored, and he will receive regular assessments of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critical care unit (CCU) transfer from the floor due to increased work of breathing. The patient has been diagnosed with pulmonary edema, confirmed by a CT chest, and has been treated with Lasix. The patient's sputum culture has revealed MSSA, and they have been started on Nafcillin for a 3-week course and levofloxacin for an 8-day course.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 62-109 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/47-171/98 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and their peripheral oxygen saturation is 98%.

The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O. They are also receiving dopamine for mean arterial pressure (MAP) in the 50s, which has been weaned to 4.

The patient has a history of allergies to morphine, amlodipine, and unknown substances. They have received various medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives.

Laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 2.0-1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 22-20 mg/dL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 193 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 118 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for alcohol abuse, acute coronary syndrome, and community-acquired pneumonia. The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is still pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Progressive acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and their BUN level is also elevated, indicating potential kidney damage.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 98%, indicating potential respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures have revealed MSSA, and they have been treated with antibiotics, but the risk of sepsis remains.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and they are receiving vasopressors, indicating potential cardiovascular instability.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological examination is incomplete, and they may be at risk for neurological complications due to their critical illness.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and they may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Infection: The patient's sputum culture has revealed MSSA, and they may be at risk for other infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   82M h/o HTN, Essential tremor presented with URI symptoms, nausea found
   to have NSTEMI at OSH transferred for cath and found to have MSSA
   pneumonia.
   Respiratory failure/Pneumonia:  MSSA growing in sputum. Reintubated
   last night for hypoxic respiratory failure. Continues to spike fevers.
   Appreciate ID input. CXR concerning for worsening RIGHT sided pna vs
   hemorrhage.
   - Continue Nafcillin for total 3 week course through [**2119-7-11**] (starting
   from [**6-21**] since Vanco started) and levofloxacin for total 8 day course
   [**2119-6-24**] through [**2119-7-2**].
   -  Pulm c/s requested for possible bronchoscopy
   - Wean from vent as tolerated. Plan to decrease Fi02 to nontoxic levels
   this morning.
   - Repeat ABG
   - F/u culture data
   - CIS
   SEPSIS: Pneumona as above. Blood culture data ngtd at this time.
   Patient illustrating septic physiology with hypotension, but may be in
   the setting of intubation. Transitioned from dopamine to levophed for
   tachycardia. Patient appears overall dry after lasix 40 mg IVx2
   yesterday.
   - 500 cc bolus x1 now
   - Levophed titrated to MAPs greater than 60. Will wean as tolerated
   - Central access obtained overnight
   - F/u cx data
   CORONARIES: NSTEMI: Cath showed clean coronaries, NSTEMI possibly
   caused by thrombus that had since resolved with medical therapy.
   Likely demand ischemia in the setting of pna.
   - Continue ASA,
   - Hold  Beta-blocker in the setting of sepsis
   - Hold plavix and heparin given concern of GI bleed
   - Continue statin
   PUMP:  Echo with newly depressed EF 35-40% with inferolat and apical
   HK.  Kept postive fluid balance overnight given septic picture in
   setting on large PNA
   - Beta-blocker on hold as above
   - Consider ACEi once clear BPs and renal function stable
   - I/O goal even to +500cc  to 1 L today
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: Cr trended up to 1.8 in setting of diuresis
   yesterday.  Baseline 1.0.
   - Renally dose meds
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient, an 82-year-old male, was admitted with a history of hypertension, essential tremor, and URI symptoms. He was found to have NSTEMI and MSSA pneumonia, and was transferred to the ICU for further management. The patient was reintubated last night for hypoxic respiratory failure and continues to spike fevers. His condition is complicated by sepsis, respiratory failure, and possible bronchoscopy.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's condition is complicated by respiratory failure, which may worsen due to the presence of MSSA pneumonia and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient is illustrating septic physiology with hypotension, tachycardia, and fever. This may lead to multi-organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
3. **Acute Renal Failure:** The patient's creatinine level has trended up to 1.8, indicating acute renal failure. This may require further management and potentially impact the patient's overall prognosis.
4. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient has a history of NSTEMI and a depressed EF of 35-40%. This may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
5. **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's CXR is concerning for worsening right-sided pneumonia or hemorrhage, which may require further evaluation and management.
6. **Thromboembolic Complications:** The patient is at risk for thromboembolic complications, such as DVT or PE, due to his immobilization and underlying medical conditions.
7. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as GI bleed, due to his anticoagulation therapy and underlying medical conditions.
8. **Infection Control:** The patient is at risk for further infection, particularly with MSSA, which may require further antibiotic therapy and infection control measures.

**Plan:**

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue Nafcillin and levofloxacin antibiotics as prescribed.
2. Wean from mechanical ventilation as tolerated.
3. Repeat ABG and culture data.
4. Consider bronchoscopy for further evaluation of respiratory failure.
5. Titrate levophed to maintain MAPs greater than 60.
6. Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust therapy accordingly.
7. Continue statin therapy for cardiac risk reduction.
8. Monitor for signs of acute renal failure and adjust therapy accordingly.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of hypertension, essential tremor, and NSTEMI, who presented with URI symptoms and was found to have MSSA pneumonia. He was reintubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. His condition is complicated by sepsis, pneumonia, and acute renal failure. He has been treated with antibiotics, pressors, and diuretics, and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Alveolar Hemorrhage (PAH): The patient's CXR is concerning for worsening right-sided pneumonia or hemorrhage. PAH is a possible complication of sepsis and pneumonia, and the patient's clinical status is being closely monitored.
2. Vasculitic Process: The patient's red cells in urine and low threshold for broadening antibiotics suggest a possible vasculitic process. Further evaluation is needed to rule out this complication.
3. GI Bleed: The patient's history of anticoagulation therapy and current use of heparin and plavix increase the risk of GI bleed. Close monitoring of the patient's GI status is necessary.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's Cr trended up to 1.8, indicating AKI. Further evaluation of his renal function is necessary to determine the underlying cause of AKI.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and close monitoring of his oxygenation and ventilation is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's NSTEMI and current septic state increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest. Close monitoring of his cardiovascular status is necessary.
7. Infection: The patient's sepsis and pneumonia increase the risk of secondary infections. Close monitoring of his infection status is necessary to prevent further complications.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's septic state and current respiratory and cardiovascular status increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy. Close monitoring of his neurological status is necessary.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient, an 82-year-old male, is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and pneumonia. He was initially diagnosed with NSTEMI and MSSA pneumonia. He was reintubated last night for hypoxic respiratory failure and continues to spike fevers.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.9°F
* Heart rate: 82 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 110/53 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Central venous pressure: 13 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.9 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 32.5%
* Platelet count: 189 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 21 mg/dL
* Glucose: 146 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: within normal range

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST
* Tidal volume: 500 mL
* Positive end-expiratory pressure: 8 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen: 50%

The patient's medications include:

* Nafcillin
* Levofloxacin
* Midazolam
* Norepinephrine
* Fentanyl
* Famotidine
* Heparin

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing Nafcillin and Levofloxacin for a total of 3 weeks and 8 days, respectively
* Weaning from the ventilator as tolerated
* Decreasing FiO2 to non-toxic levels
* Repeat ABG
* Following up on culture data
* Considering bronchoscopy

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Acute renal failure
* Cardiac complications due to NSTEMI
* GI bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
* Infection due to central line
* VAP

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Pulmonary Alveolar Hemorrhage (PAH): The patient has been diagnosed with ARDS, and the possibility of PAH is being considered. If not managed promptly, PAH can lead to respiratory failure and mortality.
2. Sepsis-Induced Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is elevated, and the differential diagnosis includes disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), shock liver, and nutritional deficiency. If not managed effectively, coagulopathy can lead to bleeding and organ failure.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is trending upward, and it is likely prerenal due to sepsis. If not managed promptly, acute renal failure can lead to end-stage renal disease and mortality.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI, and the possibility of demand ischemia in the setting of pneumonia is being considered. If not managed effectively, cardiac complications can lead to myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and mortality.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has a large A-a gradient on blood gas analysis. If not managed effectively, respiratory failure can lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory distress, and mortality.
6. Infections: The patient has MSSA pneumonia, and the possibility of anaerobic coverage is being considered. If not managed effectively, infections can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and mortality.
7. Thrombus Formation: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and is at risk for thrombus formation at the site of hypokinesis. If not managed effectively, thrombus formation can lead to cardiac complications and mortality.

To address these potential complications, the patient's treatment plan should include:

1. Aggressive management of sepsis and ARDS, including mechanical ventilation and fluid management.
2. Close monitoring of coagulation parameters and prompt treatment of coagulopathy.
3. Renal dose adjustment of medications and close monitoring of creatinine levels.
4. Cardiac monitoring and management of cardiac complications.
5. Respiratory support and management of respiratory failure.
6. Infection control measures, including coverage for anaerobes.
7. Anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombus formation.

The patient's treatment plan should be closely monitored and adjusted as needed to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-inch tall adult in the ICU with a chief complaint of fever, 101.9°F, and has been experiencing a 24-hour fever. The patient has a history of acute coronary syndrome, pneumonia, and acute renal failure. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 110/53 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 189 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and white blood cell count may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's mechanical ventilation and elevated respiratory rate may indicate the presence of ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and death if not managed appropriately.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not managed promptly, leading to AKI and potential need for dialysis.
4. Pulmonary Alveolar Hemorrhage (PAH): The patient's chest X-ray may show evidence of PAH, which can lead to respiratory failure and death if not managed promptly.
5. Vasculitis: The patient's red blood cells in the urine may indicate the presence of vasculitis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not managed promptly.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and white blood cell count may indicate the presence of an infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not managed promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in their condition.
2. Adjust the patient's mechanical ventilation settings as necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Continue to provide antibiotics as prescribed to treat the patient's pneumonia and acute renal failure.
4. Consider adding vasopressors to support the patient's blood pressure if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's urine output and consider initiating dialysis if necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist or intensivist to optimize the patient's mechanical ventilation and respiratory management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including hypertension, essential tremor, and a recent NSTEMI. He was initially admitted with URI symptoms and later found to have MSSA pneumonia, which led to reintubation for hypoxic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is concerning for worsening right-sided pneumonia versus hemorrhage, as evident from the CXR. He has a fever of 101.9°F, and his respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 97%. His hemodynamic status is also unstable, with a MAP of 110/53 mmHg and a CVP of 13 mmHg.

The patient has received multiple antibiotics, including nafcillin and levofloxacin, and has been treated with levophed for hypotension. His blood cultures are pending, and his urine culture showed red cells, prompting a consideration of vasculitic process.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening right-sided pneumonia and hypoxic respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory compromise, including respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology, including hypotension and tachycardia, may worsen if not managed promptly.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's Cr trended up to 1.8 mg/dL, and his I/O goal is to maintain a balance of 500-1000 cc to prevent further deterioration.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and depressed EF may lead to further cardiac compromise, including cardiac arrest.
5. GI bleed: The patient's hold on plavix and heparin due to concern of GI bleed may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Vasculitic process: The patient's urine culture showing red cells and the consideration of vasculitic process may lead to further vascular compromise.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, hemodynamic, and cardiac status. His antibiotics should be continued, and his blood cultures should be closely monitored for any signs of sepsis. His fluid balance should be closely monitored to prevent further deterioration of his renal function. His cardiac status should be closely monitored, and his beta-blocker should be held until his septic physiology improves.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is secondary to multilobar pneumonia, and there is a risk of further deterioration if not managed appropriately.
2. Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis is complicated by coagulopathy, hyperbilirubinemia, and acute renal failure, which can lead to organ dysfunction if not managed promptly.
3. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia is complicated by an enlarging right-sided infiltrate, which may require further treatment and monitoring.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, with a history of NSTEMI, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications if not managed appropriately.
5. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine is trending upwards, and there is a risk of further renal failure if not managed promptly.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia and coagulopathy may be secondary to nutritional deficiencies, which need to be addressed promptly.
7. Infection control issues: The patient's presence in the ICU increases the risk of hospital-acquired infections, which need to be monitored and managed promptly.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI and PUMP make him at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's management plan includes:

1. Ventilatory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and the plan is to continue this support as needed.
2. Antibiotic therapy: The patient is receiving antibiotics for MSSA pneumonia, and the plan is to continue this therapy for a total of 3 weeks.
3. Fluid management: The patient is receiving fluid resuscitation, and the plan is to continue this support as needed.
4. Coagulopathy management: The patient's coagulopathy is being managed with vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia management: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia is being managed with vitamin K and cholestyramine.
6. Renal failure management: The patient's renal failure is being managed with diuretics and fluid restriction.
7. Nutritional support: The patient is receiving nutritional support, including enteral nutrition and parenteral nutrition as needed.
8. Infection control measures: The patient is receiving infection control measures, including antibiotics and isolation precautions.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

   thrombus that had since resolved with medical therapy.  Likely demand
   ischemia in the setting of pneumonia.
   -          Continue ASA

Summary:

The patient is a 82-year-old male admitted with NSTEMI, now with MSSA pneumonia complicated by sepsis, and an enlarging right-sided infiltrate. He has persistent fevers, and his condition is being managed with antibiotics, ventilation, and fluid resuscitation. The patient has coagulopathy, hyperbilirubinemia, and acute renal failure, and is at risk for complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening pneumonia: The patient's persistent fevers and enlarging right-sided infiltrate indicate a high risk of worsening pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is not responding to antibiotics, and there is a risk of septic shock and multi-organ failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is not fully resolved, and there is a risk of bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine is slowly trending up, and there is a risk of worsening renal failure, particularly if he develops septic shock.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia, particularly if he is not adequately ventilated or if there is inadequate control of his respiratory status.
6. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis, particularly if he is not adequately anticoagulated.
7. Acute respiratory distress syndrome: The patient is at risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome, particularly if his oxygenation status deteriorates.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI is not fully resolved, and there is a risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and adjust dosing as needed based on culture data.
2. Monitor the patient's oxygenation status and adjust ventilation as needed to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dosing of medications as needed to prevent worsening renal failure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust therapy as needed to prevent bleeding complications.
6. Consider echocardiogram to assess cardiac function and guide therapy.
7. Consider stress testing to assess cardiac function and guide therapy.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed to prevent acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 82-year-old male admitted with NSTEMI, now complicated by MSSA pneumonia, sepsis, and enlarging right-sided infiltrate. He has been treated with antibiotics and is currently on assist control ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. His condition is complicated by coagulopathy, with an elevated INR of 2.4, and acute renal failure with a slow trending up of creatinine.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, particularly in the kidneys and liver.
2. Respiratory failure, potentially leading to ARDS or respiratory arrest.
3. Coagulopathy-related bleeding or thrombotic events, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
4. Acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, potentially requiring dialysis.
5. Cardiovascular instability, including cardiac arrest or arrhythmias, given the patient's history of NSTEMI and potential demand ischemia.
6. Nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin K deficiency, which may exacerbate coagulopathy.
7. Potential for prolonged ICU stay and increased risk of hospital-acquired infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Given the patient's complex condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and to adjust treatment accordingly. Regular communication with the patient's family and other healthcare providers is also crucial to ensure optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of fever, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and vitamin K deficiency. The patient has been receiving antibiotics and has had persistent fevers, with a peak temperature of 102.8°F. The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a MAP over 55 mmHg. The patient is receiving cautious fluid resuscitation and has had no new culture data as of 10:30 PM. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.2, hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 294 K/uL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fevers and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient's oxygenation index is 58, which may indicate a risk of respiratory failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's vitamin K deficiency and elevated international normalized ratio (INR) suggest a risk of coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels suggest a risk of renal failure.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient's conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) suggest a risk of hepatic failure.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia may indicate cardiovascular instability, which can lead to cardiac arrest.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity may indicate neurological complications, such as sepsis-related encephalopathy or hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's nausea and vomiting may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as small bowel obstruction or inflammatory bowel disease.
9. Infectious complications: The patient's persistent fevers and elevated white blood cell count suggest a risk of infectious complications, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection.
10. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's risk factors for VTE, including immobility and hypercoagulability, suggest a risk of VTE, which can lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.

   82M with hypertension, essential tremor admitted with NSTEMI, now with
   MSSA pneumonia complicated by sepsis, enlarging right sided infiltrate
   1. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Secondary to multilobar pneumonia.
   Continues on AC; RSBI 58.
   -          Vent parameters per ARDSnet protocol
   -          Pulmonary recs
   -          Pneumonia treatment as below
   -          Prior to extubation, will need diuresis given large volume
   resuscitation during this hospital course
   2. Pneumonia/sepsis:  MSSA pneumonia. Patient with persistent fevers.
   ID involved.
   -          Repeat CT chest to assess for loculation or worsening
   pleural effusion
   -          Consider expanding anaerobic coverage
   -          Continue Nafcillin for total 3 week course through [**2119-7-11**]
   (start date [**6-21**], Vancomycin initiation date) and levofloxacin for
   total 8 day course ([**2119-6-24**] through [**2119-7-2**])
   -          Follow culture data
   -          Maintain CVP 8-12, MAP>60; if falls below this, bolus IVF;
   wean Levophed as tolerated
   -          CIS
   -          If bilirubin continues to rise, get RUQ ultrasound to assess
   for cholecystitis
   3. Coagulopathy:  INR improved to 1.4 with vitamin K 5mg PO x1.
   Differential includes DIC (FDP 10-40, although elevated fibrinogen and
   PTT normal), shock liver (LFTs improved since admission). Could also be
   nutritional deficiency.
   4. Hyperbilirubinemia:  Direct. Thus DIC less likely. This may be
   secondary to cholestasis in setting of acute illness.
   -          Trend bilirubin
   -          As above, if bilirubin continues to rise, get RUQ ultrasound
   to assess for cholecystitis
   5. Abnormal diff:  Differential for monocytosis includes infectious
   etiology, malignancy. Given presence of atypical cells, raises concern
   for malignancy.
   -          Peripheral smear
   6. Acute renal failure:  Baseline 1.0. Creatinine slowly trending up,
   likely prerenal given sepsis.
   -          Renally dose meds
   7. s/p NSTEMI: Cath showed clean coronaries, NSTEMI possibly caused by
   thrombus that had since resolved with medical therapy.  Likely demand
   ischemia in the setting of pneumonia.
   -          Continue ASA
   -          Hold beta-blocker in the setting of sepsis
   -          Hold Plavix at this time
   -          Continue statin
   8. PUMP:  TTE with newly depressed EF 35-40% with inferolateral and
   apical hypokinesis
   -          Beta-blocker on hold as above
   -          Would benefit from ACE inhibitor once over acute illness
   -          Restart heparin gtt for prevention of thrombus formation

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male admitted with NSTEMI, now complicated by MSSA pneumonia, sepsis, and enlarging right-sided infiltrate. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 102.8°F, blood pressure of 109/51 mmHg, heart rate of 86 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 10.2 K/uL
* Hct: 33.1%
* Plt: 294 K/uL
* Cr: 2.0 mg/dL
* TCO2: 25 mmHg
* Glucose: 106 mg/dL
* Lactic Acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 366 IU/L
* Ca++: 6.6 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to multilobar pneumonia
* Pneumonia/sepsis caused by MSSA
* Coagulopathy with INR of 1.4
* Hyperbilirubinemia with direct bilirubin
* Abnormal differential count with monocytosis
* Acute renal failure with baseline creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL
* s/p NSTEMI with clean coronaries
* PUMP with newly depressed EF 35-40%

The patient is receiving treatment for pneumonia, sepsis, and coagulopathy, including antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and supportive care. The patient's medications include:

* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Levofloxacin
* Nafcillin
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam (Versed)
* Norepinephrine
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction, particularly respiratory and cardiovascular failure
* Pneumonia progression, leading to worsening hypoxia and respiratory failure
* Coagulopathy progression, leading to bleeding complications
* Hyperbilirubinemia progression, leading to liver failure
* Acute renal failure progression, leading to end-stage renal disease
* PUMP dysfunction, leading to cardiac failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent and manage these potential complications.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 EKG - At [**2119-6-27**] 08:20 PM
 FEVER - 101.6
F - [**2119-6-27**] 04:00 PM
   - Decision made to keep patient on CCU service instead of transfer to
   MICU
   - Added Flagyl IV for anaerobic coverage
   - CT Torso - Wet read - Worsening bilateral edema, although worsening
   underlying penumonia is an increasing likely possibility given
   persistent fevers. Abd benign.
   - RUQ u/s - Wet read - Diffusely echogenic liver, compatible with fatty
   infiltration. No focal hepatic lesion. No biliary dilatation.
   - Started on lasix gtt 5 mg/hr. +400 cc at 7 pm and increased to 8
   mg/hr. Good UOP but still +400 cc at MN.
   - Cr 2.5 > 2.7 > 2.9
   - Levophed weaned off 1pm. No pressors since.
   - Rechecked BNP - [**Numeric Identifier 6066**] (admission) > 5926
   - Pulmonary recs - Follow central venous O2 (First O2 sat 73) Consider
   am cortisol if persistent hypotension. Advise CT torso. Consider
   amylase lipase. Decrease FiO2 to 0.4. Pulm toilet, HOB up, Peridex,

 will go ahead and start

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, which can progress to septic shock if not managed promptly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a community-acquired bacterial pneumonia, which can worsen and lead to respiratory failure if not treated effectively.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, which can indicate acute kidney injury or acute renal failure. This can lead to fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances if not managed properly.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged INR, which can increase the risk of bleeding. This can be managed with vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's bilirubin levels are elevated, which can indicate liver dysfunction or cholestasis. This can be managed with supportive care and monitoring of liver function tests.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a diagnosis of hypoxic respiratory failure, which can worsen if not managed with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of NSTEMI and a recent catheterization showed clean coronaries, but the patient still has a depressed ejection fraction. This can increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has diarrhea, which can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances if not managed promptly.
9. Central Venous Catheter-Related Complications: The patient has a central venous catheter, which can increase the risk of catheter-related bloodstream infections or thrombosis.
10. Skin Integrity Complications: The patient has impaired skin integrity, which can increase the risk of pressure ulcers or skin breakdown.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management by the ICU team, including:

* Mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy for respiratory failure
* Antibiotics and supportive care for pneumonia
* Renal replacement therapy for acute renal failure
* Vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma for coagulopathy
* Supportive care and monitoring for hyperbilirubinemia
* Cardiovascular medications and monitoring for cardiovascular complications
* Gastrointestinal support and monitoring for diarrhea
* Central venous catheter care and monitoring for catheter-related complications
* Pressure ulcer prevention and skin care for impaired skin integrity.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male admitted with NSTEMI, now with MSSA pneumonia complicated by sepsis. The patient's condition has been unstable, with persistent fevers, worsening bilateral edema, and acute renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.6°F (38.7°C)
* Heart rate: 89 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 146/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient is sedated and intubated, with an endotracheal tube in place. He has decreased breath sounds on the right base and is receiving oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 36 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 18 mmol/L
* Glucose: 119 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 366 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

The patient has a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, pneumonia, acute renal failure, and alcohol abuse. He is also at risk for pulmonary edema and has a history of NSTEMI.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning to pressure support as tolerated
* Continuing diuresis
* Maintaining CVP 8-12 and MAP >60 mmHg
* Continuing antibiotics for MSSA pneumonia
* Monitoring for coagulopathy and hyperbilirubinemia
* Renally dosing medications
* Expecting improvement in acute renal failure with diuresis
* Holding beta-blocker and Plavix due to sepsis
* Continuing statin and ASA

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 10 mL/hour
* Glycemic control: Blood glucose well-controlled
* Lines: Arterial line and multi-lumen line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's disposition is to continue in the ICU for further management.
